thread.title: Jaguars' tight end Julius Thomas still probably a week away
thread.title_full: Jaguars' tight end Julius Thomas still probably a week away

author: Ryan O'Halloran
title: Jaguars' tight end Julius Thomas still probably a week away
text:
Jaguars' tight end Julius Thomas still probably a week away 
By Ryan O'Halloran Wed, Oct 7, 2015 @ 9:32 pm | updated Wed, Oct 7, 2015 @ 10:51 pm Photos AP Jacksonville Jaguars tight end Julius Thomas makes a reception against the Pittsburgh Steelers during the first half of an NFL preseason football game, Friday, Aug. 14, 2015, in Jacksonville, Fla. Videos Read the latest Jaguars coverage 
Close, but not quite there. 
That was the update from Jaguars tight end Julius Thomas about his right hand before practice Wednesday, when he caught passes for the first time since being injured Aug. 14 and having surgery Sept. 1. 
Thomas has not been cleared to play in Sunday’s game at Tampa Bay. 
“I’m still limited,” he said. “I don’t know if [playing] is going to be an option yet.” 
Thomas will be guided by the Jaguars medical team’s advice. 
“I’m really going to lean on those guys and follow their plan so hopefully nothing else happens,” he said. 
Thomas did two weeks of side-field work and one week of practice that included running routes in team drills but not catching a pass. He still has not gone through a full workout. 
The most likely projection is that Thomas will sit out the Buccaneers game and debut at home against Houston in Week 6. 
Thomas stopped wearing a cast in practice, but he wouldn’t reveal what kind of contraption he will have on the hand. 
“I will definitely have to put some stuff on it to try and practice and then it will be about getting a feel for things and adjusting and doing the things I’ll have to do to protect myself out there,” he said. 
Thomas said there isn’t a specific hurdle — one practice, back-to-back workouts, a week of activity — he must clear before playing in a game. 
“It’s going to be a continuous process working with the doctors,” he said. “I’ll work my back and if the doctors are confident with the things I’m doing, they’ll let me do a little more and challenge me. It’s going to be a day-by-day situation, really.”
